messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Elliotte Rusty Harold <elharo@m...> wrote:
> ...
> @BeforeTest/@BeforeSuite is more descriptive than @Before/@BeforeClass.
> I prefer it. I might want to go even further and change @Before to
> @BeforeEachTest but maybe that's going to far.
>
>
> On the flip side, @Before is easier to type than @BeforeClass. This
> means programmers are more likely to use it, which is more likely to be
> correct. I'm afraid if we change @Before to @BeforeTest then a lot of
> code will end up in @BeforeClass/@BeforeSuite that doesn't belong there.
> ...

Thank you for your reply,
You're right, it is easier to type, but this doesn't compensate the
lack of clarity in my opinion. Plus, you normally don't write more
than one @BeforeTest method per class. I also think(hope) that most
programmers choose the modules they use depending on what those
modules do, not on how long their names are... The shorter names may
also be the cause of misunderstandings (since they are less clear)
which can result in code being put into places where it doesn't belong.
